facts.text: Misc. Petition No. 537 of 1969 filed by respondent No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: High Court at Jabalpur in Misc. Petition No. 537 of 1969. N. Shroff, for the Appellants. N. Phadke, Anthoney G. Menezes, P. G. Bhartari, J. B. Dadachanji, O. C. Mathur Ravinder Narain, for respondent No. 1

facts.text: In the Judicial Service of Madhya Pradesh there are three classes of officers: Civil Judges, Additional District and Sessions Judges and District Judges.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by ALAGIRISWAMI, J.-In the Judicial Service of Madhya Pradesh there are three classes of officers, Civil Judges, Additional District and Sessions Judges and District Judges but under the Madhya Pradesh Civil Courts Act, 1958

facts.text: Under the Madhya Pradesh Civil Courts Act, 1958 there are four classes of Civil Courts: the Court of the District Judge, the Court of the Addl. District Judge, the Court of the Civil Judge Class 1 and the Court of the Civil Judge Class II.

anchor.surface_text: District Judges but under the Madhya Pradesh Civil Courts Act, 1958 there are four classes of Civil Courts, the Court of the District Judge, the Court of the Addl. District Judge, the Court of the Civil Judge  Class 1  and the Court of the Civil Judge  Class II .

facts.text: Respondent No. 1, Shri B. A. Nigam, entered service as a Civil Judge on 20-10-1956 in Madhya Bharat.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent No. 1, Shri B. A. Nigam, entered service as a Civil Judge on 20-10-1956 in Madhya Bharat. After Madhya Bharat became part of Madhya Pradesh he was absorbed as a Civil Judge and placed for purposes of seniority at No. 189.

facts.text: After Madhya Bharat became part of Madhya Pradesh, Shri B. A. Nigam was absorbed as a Civil Judge and placed for purposes of seniority at No. 189.

anchor.surface_text: After Madhya Bharat became part of Madhya Pradesh he was absorbed as a Civil Judge and placed for purposes of seniority at No. 189. From the time when the Madhya Pradesh Civil Court Act, 1958 came into force

facts.text: From the time when the Madhya Pradesh Civil Courts Act, 1958 came into force, some period of service of a Civil Judge during which he exercised powers of Civil Judge, Class 1, however small, was considered a necessary qualification for promotion to the post of Additional District and Sessions Judge.

anchor.surface_text: From the time when the Madhya Pradesh Civil Court Act, 1958 came into force some period of service of a Civil Judge during which he exercised powers of Civil Judge, Class 1, however, small, was companysidered a necessary qualification for promotion to the post of Additional District and Sessions Judge.

facts.text: On or about May 3, 1968, by a resolution of the High Court it was laid down that selection of a Civil Judge, Class II, as a Civil Judge, Class I, shall be deemed as promotion and that being so, only the cases of Civil Judges, Class I, shall be considered for promotion as Additional District and Sessions Judges.

anchor.surface_text: On or about May 3, 1968, by a resolution of the High Court it was laid down that selection of a Civil Judge, Class 11, as a Civil Judge, Class I, shall be deemed as promotion and that being so, only the cases of Civil Judges, Class 1, shall be companysidered for promotion as Additional District and Sessions Judges

facts.text: According to the Service Rules there is only one class of Civil Judges.

anchor.surface_text: It must be made clear at the outset that according to the Service Rules there is only one class of Civil Judges and Jr number two classes of Civil Judges  Class 1  and Civil Judges  Class II .

facts.text: Fitness of respondent No. 1 for promotion as Civil Judge, Class I, considered on May 3, 1966, August 12, 1966, April 17, 1967, November 6, 1967 and April 18, 1968 and found unfit each time.

anchor.surface_text: The fitness of the respondent  1  for promotion as Civil Judge, Class I, seems to have been companysidered on a number of occasions i.e. on May 3, 1966, August 12, 1966, April 17, 1967. November 6, 1967 and April 18, 1968 and on each of these occasions he was number found fit to exercise powers of a Civil Judge, Class 1.

facts.text: Appellants showed the file containing proceedings of Judges meetings of High Court of MP on various dates where names considered, and Supreme Court scrutinized and found no reason to doubt bona fides.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. N. Shroff appearing for the appellants has also shown us the file companytaining the proceedings of the Judges meetings of the High Court of Madhya Pradesh on the various dates above referred to in which the names of various officers for being Posted as Class I Civil Judges have been companysidered. We have scrutinised them carefully and can see numberreason to doubt the bona fide nature of the. decisions therein made.

facts.text: High Court held that juniors exercised Class I powers without considering respondent's claim, but even if considered, he would not have been found fit.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has also taken the view that though the junior members in the cadre of Civil Judges had often been allowed to exercise the powers of Civil Judge, Class 1, without companysidering at that time the respondents claim and then those junior members had been preferred for promotion on the ground that they had exercised such powers, and such preference was open to attack as being violative of the fundamental rights of the respondent, they companyld number assist him on that ground because even if his claims for exercising the powers of Civil Judge, Class I had been companysidered at the appropriate time, he would number have been found fit for the purpose for the reason earlier mentioned.

facts.text: On 30-11-1968 the respondent was found fit to be posted as a Civil Judge, Class I.

anchor.surface_text: Finally, on 30-11-1968 the respondent was found fit to be posted as a Civil Judge, Class I and he filed the petition, out of which this appeal arises,

facts.text: After being found fit on 30-11-1968, respondent filed petition for consideration for promotion as Additional District and Sessions Judge over heads of others.

anchor.surface_text: Finally, on 30-11-1968 the respondent was found fit to be posted as a Civil Judge, Class I and he filed the petition, out of which this appeal arises, for companysideration of his name for being promoted as an Additional District and Sessions Judge over the heads of all the people who had been earlier found to have better qualifications for being posted as Civil Judges, Class I in preference to him.

facts.text: Petition allowed by the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: That petition having been allowed by the High Court his appeal has been filed by certificate by the Registrar of the High Court of Madhya Pradesh and the State against the judgment of that High Court.

facts.text: Appeal filed by certificate by the Registrar of the High Court of Madhya Pradesh and the State.

anchor.surface_text: That petition having been allowed by the High Court his appeal has been filed by certificate by the Registrar of the High Court of Madhya Pradesh and the State against the judgment of that High Court.

facts.text: High Court issued writ of mandamus directing consideration of respondent's claim for promotion in relation to juniors and consequential benefits if found fit.

anchor.surface_text: Having held rightly, according to us, that till November 30, 1968 the respondent No. 1 was number qualified to be companysidered for promotion as an Additional District and Sessions Judge, the High Court curiously enough issued a writ of mandamus directing that the respondents claim for promotion should be companysidered in relation to the claims of his juniors and if he was found fit he should be allowed the companysequential benefits including fixing of seniority in the cadre of Additional District and Sessions Judges.

facts.text: Out of 41 respondents in petition, 10 found fit in 1962, one in 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Out of the 41 people whom the respondent No. 1 had made respondents to his petition, 10 people were found fit in 1962 and one in 1963.

facts.text: 3 others found superior on 3-5-66 along with respondent.

anchor.surface_text: Then we have 3 others whose claims were companysidered on 3-5-66 alongwith that of the respondent No. 1 and found superior to his.

facts.text: 8 others superior on 12-8-66.

anchor.surface_text: There are 8 others whose claims were companypared to the respondents on 12-8-66 and found to be superior to his.

facts.text: 17 others superior on 17-4-67, 2 on 7-11-67.

anchor.surface_text: Seventeen others, whose claims were companypared to the respondents on 17-4-67 were found to be superior to the respondents and two were found superior to the respondent on 7-11-67.

facts.text: Jurisdiction of Class II Civil Judges up to Rs. 5,000, Class I up to Rs. 10,000.

anchor.surface_text: While it is true that the Service Rules do number provide for Civil Judges being classed as Class I Civil Judges and Class II Civil Judges, we cannot ignore the fact that the jurisdiction of the Class II civil Judges is only upto Rs. 5,000 and that of Class I Civil Judges upto Rs. 10,000.

facts.text: Supreme Court allows the appeal and sets aside the judgment of the Madhya Pradesh High Court.

anchor.surface_text: We see numbermerits in his claim. We, therefore, allow the appeal and set aside the judgment of the Madhya Pradesh High Court. There will, however, be numberorder as to companyts.

concepts.unlisted_label: Canons of Fair Play and Justice

issues.text: Whether the resolution of the High Court dated May 3, 1968, deeming selection to Civil Judge Class I as promotion and requiring such experience for ADSJ promotion, is valid given that Service Rules provide for only one class of Civil Judges and power to create classes vests with the Government.

anchor.surface_text: From the time the Act came into force, service as Civil Judge exercising Class I powers was necessary for promotionMadhya Pradesh Civil Court Act, 1958 came into force some period of service of a Civil Judge during which he exercised powers of Civil Judge, Class 1, however, small, was considered a necessary qualification for promotion to the post of Additional District and Sessions Judge. On or about May 3, 1968, by a resolution of the High Court it was laid down that selection of a Civil Judge, Class 11, as a Civil Judge, Class I, shall be deemed as promotion and that being so, only the cases of Civil Judges, Class 1, shall be considered for promotion as Additional District and Sessions Judges in order of their seniority. It must be made clear at the outset that according to the Service Rules there is only one class of Civil Judges and Jr number two classes of Civil Judges  Class 1  and Civil Judges  Class II .

issues.text: Whether requiring experience exercising powers of Civil Judge Class I has a rational relation to suitability for promotion to Additional District and Sessions Judge.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court took the view that as for some years past a principle for selection had been introduced that before a Civil Judge was promoted to the post of an Additional District and Sessions Judge, it was essential that he should have exercised the powers of Civil Judge, Class 1, for a period, however short and that principle had a rational relation to the suitability of Civil Judges for promotion to posts of Additional District and Sessions Judges and the respondent No. 1 could not legitimately complain, as he did not have that qualification, and he could not be, selected for promotion only on the basis of seniority.

issues.text: Whether preferring juniors who exercised Class I powers over the respondent without considering his claim violated his fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has also taken the view that though the junior members in the cadre of Civil Judges had often been allowed to exercise the powers of Civil Judge, Class 1, without considering at that time the respondents claim and then those junior members had been preferred for promotion on the ground that they had exercised such powers, and such preference was open to attack as being violative of the fundamental rights of the respondent, they could not assist him on that ground because even if his claims for exercising the powers of Civil Judge, Class I had been considered at the appropriate time, he would not have been found fit for the purpose for the reason earlier mentioned.

issues.text: Whether there is reason to doubt the bona fide nature of the High Court decisions finding the respondent unfit for Civil Judge Class I on multiple occasions.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. N. Shroff appearing for the appellants has also shown us the file containing the proceedings of the Judges meetings of the High Court of Madhya Pradesh on the various dates above referred to in which the names of various officers for being Posted as Class I Civil Judges have been considered. We have scrutinised them carefully and can see no reason to doubt the bona fide nature of the decisions therein made.

issues.text: Whether a writ of mandamus should issue directing consideration of the respondent's promotion claim against his juniors with consequential seniority benefits if found fit.

anchor.surface_text: Having held rightly, according to us, that till November 30, 1968 the respondent No. 1 was not qualified to be considered for promotion as an Additional District and Sessions Judge, the High Court curiously enough issued a writ of mandamus directing that the respondents claim for promotion should be considered in relation to the claims of his juniors and if he was found fit he should be allowed the consequential benefits including fixing of seniority in the cadre of Additional District and Sessions Judges.

issues.text: Whether the respondent's promotion claim should be considered based on original seniority in Civil Judges cadre ignoring prior unfitness findings and Class I qualification, given the rational nexus of the requirement.

anchor.surface_text: Once it is found that experience as Civil Judge, Class 1, at least for a short period, is a necessary qualification for promotion as Additional District and Sessions Judge and that such a requirement has a rational relation to the question at issue, it would be surprising to hold that a man, who again and again had been found unfit to be posted as Civil Judge, Class 1, in comparison with others, who were his juniors in service, his claim for promotion as Additional District and Sessions Judge should be decided not on the basis of the date on which he was found fit to exercise the powers of Civil Judge, Class I, but on the basis of the date of his entry into service.

issues.text: Whether allowing the respondent promotion over those found superior earlier would be a mockery of all canons of fair play and justice.

anchor.surface_text: We are firmly of opinion that in the face of these circumstances to allow the respondent No. 1 to be considered for promotion as Additional District and Sessions Judge in preference to others who had been found better qualified to be posted as Civil Judges Class I much earlier merely on the basis of the date of his entry into service would be a mockery of all canons of fair play and justice.

arguments.claim: Resolution of High Court dated May 3, 1968 deeming selection to Civil Judge Class I as promotion is invalid as Service Rules provide only one class of Civil Judges and power to create classes vests with Government not High Court

anchor.surface_text: In addition to the point which we have earlier mentioned and agreed with the High Court, his only other contention was that in the list of Civil Judges he was senior to all of them and as there was no provision in the service rules for classifying Civil Judges as Class I or Class II and the power to create various classes of services was one which vested with the Government and not with the High Court therefore the resolution of the High Court of May 3, 1968 cannot affect him adversely.

holdings.text: we, therefore, agree with this conclusion of the High Court.

Having held rightly, according to us, that till November 30, 1968 the respondent No. 1 was not qualified to be considered for promotion as an Additional District and Sessions Judge, the High Court curiously enough issued a writ of mandamus

holdings.reasoning_summary: Supreme Court affirms High Court's correct holding that respondent lacked necessary Class I experience qualification until 30-11-1968.

holdings.text: Once it is found that experience as Civil Judge, Class 1, at least for a short period, is a necessary qualification for promotion as Additional District and Sessions Judge and that such a requirement has a rational relation to the question at issue, it would be surprising to hold that a man, who again and again had been found unfit to be posted as Civil Judge, Class 1, in comparison with others, who were his juniors in service, his claim for promotion as Additional District and Sessions Judge should be decided not on the basis of the date on which he was found fit to exercise the powers of Civil Judge, Class I, but on the basis of the date of his entry into service.

anchor.surface_text: In mentioning about the juniors of the respondent No. 1 the learned Judges were referring to the original seniority in the cadre of Civil Judges. Once it is found that experience as Civil Judge, Class 1, at least for a short period, is a necessary qualification for promotion as Additional District and Sessions Judge and that such a requirement has a rational relation to the question at issue, it would be surprising to hold that a man, who again and again had been found unfit to be posted as Civil Judge, Class 1, in comparison with others, who were his juniors in service, his claim for promotion as Additional District and Sessions Judge should be decided not on the basis of the date on which he was found fit to exercise the powers of Civil Judge, Class I, but on the basis of the date of his entry into service.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Given rational nexus of Class I experience to promotion suitability, claim cannot ignore date of acquiring qualification and prior unfitness vs juniors.

holdings.text: The High Court has rightly held that such a provision cannot be said to be irrelevant to the question of promotion from among the Civil Judges to Additional District and Sessions Judges.

anchor.surface_text: We have already pointed out that the High Court has rightly held that such a provision cannot be said to be irrelevant to the question of promotion from among the Civil Judges to Additional District and Sessions Judges.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirming High Court: requiring Class I powers experience rationally relates to suitability for Additional District and Sessions Judge promotion.

holdings.text: The resolution of the High Court of May 1963 should not be interpreted literally. If it is done in its proper background it would be appreciated that what was done was not to create a new class of Civil Judges called Class I Civil Judges but to have a list of persons who were qualified to be posted as Class I Civil Judges and to provide that fitness for being posted as Class I Civil Judges and acting as such for some time should be considered as a Qualification for promotion as Additional District and Sessions Judges.

anchor.surface_text: While it is true that the Service Rules do not provide for Civil Judges being classed as Class I Civil Judges and Class II Civil Judges, we cannot ignore the fact that the jurisdiction of the Class II civil Judges is only upto Rs. 5,000 and that of Class I Civil Judges upto Rs. 10,000. The resolution of the High Court of May 1963 should not be interpreted literally. If it is done in its proper background it would be appreciated that what was done was not to create a new class of Civil Judges called Class I Civil Judges but to have a list of persons who were qualified to be posted as Class I Civil Judges and to provide that fitness for being posted as Class I Civil Judges and acting as such for some time should be considered as a Qualification for promotion as Additional District and Sessions Judges.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Resolution lays down qualification list for Class I posting as promotion prerequisite, not creating new service class beyond Service Rules.

holdings.text: We are firmly of opinion that in the face of these circumstances to allow the respondent No. 1 to be considered for promotion as Additional District and Sessions Judge in preference to others who had been found better qualified to be posted as Civil Judges Class I much earlier merely on the basis of the date of his entry into service would be a mockery of all canons of fair play and justice.

anchor.surface_text: We are firmly of opinion that in the face of these circumstances to allow the respondent No. 1 to be considered for promotion as Additional District and Sessions Judge in preference to others who had been found better qualified to be posted as Civil Judges Class I much earlier merely on the basis of the date of his entry into service would be a mockery of all canons of fair play and justice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Promoting respondent over earlier-found superiors based solely on entry seniority subverts merit, fair play, and justice.

holdings.text: We see no merits in his claim. We, therefore, allow the appeal and set aside the judgment of the Madhya Pradesh High Court.

anchor.surface_text: We see no merits in his claim. We, therefore, allow the appeal and set aside the judgment of the Madhya Pradesh High Court. There will, however, be no order as to costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative holdings reject respondent's claims; appeal succeeds, High Court mandamus set aside.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. N. Shroff appearing for the appellants has also shown us the file containing the proceedings of the Judges meetings of the High Court of Madhya Pradesh on the various dates above referred to in which the names of various officers for being Posted as Class I Civil Judges have been considered. We have scrutinised them carefully and can see no reason to doubt the bona fide nature of the decisions therein made.
We, therefore, allow the appeal and set aside the judgment of the Madhya Pradesh High Court. There will, however, be numberorder as to companyts.

anchor.surface_text: They also took the view that since the respondent No. 1 had not acquired the qualification required for promotion, his claim for such promotion should be regarded as having been considered and rejected by implication till November 30, 1968 when he was allowed to exercise the powers of Civil Judge, Class I. Having held rightly, according to us, that till November 30, 1968 the respondent No. 1 was not qualified to be considered for promotion as an Additional District and Sessions Judge, the High Court curiously enough issued a writ of mandamus
We, therefore, allow the appeal and set aside the judgment of the Madhya Pradesh High Court. There will, however, be numberorder as to companyts.

In mentioning about the juniors of the respondent No. 1 the learned Judges were referring to the original seniority in the cadre of Civil Judges. Once it is found that experience as Civil Judge, Class 1, at least for a short period, is a necessary qualification for promotion as Additional District and Sessions Judge and that such a requirement has a rational relation to the question at issue, it would be surprising to hold that a man, who again and again had been found unfit to be posted as Civil Judge, Class 1, in comparison with others, who were his juniors in service, his claim for promotion as Additional District and Sessions Judge should be decided not on the basis of the date on which he was found fit to exercise the powers of Civil Judge, Class I, but on the basis of the date of his entry into service.
We, therefore, allow the appeal and set aside the judgment of the Madhya Pradesh High Court. There will, however, be numberorder as to companyts.

anchor.surface_text: We have already pointed out that the High Court has rightly held that such a provision cannot be said to be irrelevant to the question of promotion from among the Civil Judges to Additional District and Sessions Judges.
We, therefore, allow the appeal and set aside the judgment of the Madhya Pradesh High Court. There will, however, be numberorder as to companyts.

anchor.surface_text: While it is true that the Service Rules do not provide for Civil Judges being classed as Class I Civil Judges and Class II Civil Judges, we cannot ignore the fact that the jurisdiction of the Class II civil Judges is only upto Rs. 5,000 and that of Class I Civil Judges upto Rs. 10,000. The resolution of the High Court of May 1963 should not be interpreted literally. If it is done in its proper background it would be appreciated that what was done was not to create a new class of Civil Judges called Class I Civil Judges but to have a list of persons who were qualified to be posted as Class I Civil Judges and to provide that fitness for being posted as Class I Civil Judges and acting as such for some time should be considered as a Qualification for promotion as Additional District and Sessions Judges.
We, therefore, allow the appeal and set aside the judgment of the Madhya Pradesh High Court. There will, however, be numberorder as to companyts.
